questions.text: A 54-year-old male patient presented with easy fatigability, tiredness, along some abdominal discomfort. Physical examination revealed splenomegaly. Routine laboratory findings show mildly reduced haemoglobin and markedly increased WBC count to 60000/cu mm with eosinophilia and basophilia. A peripheral smear was prepared, and an image of which is shown below. Based on the above findings, what is your probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Marked leukocytosis (>60,000/cu mm) with eosinophilia and basophilia is characteristic of Chronic Myeloid Leukaemia (CML)
  • Peripheral smear shows myeloid precursors at all stages: promyelocytes, myelocytes, metamyelocytes, and mature neutrophils
  • The presence of basophils and eosinophils is highly suggestive of CML
  • Clinical features like splenomegaly, fatigue, and a chronic course support the diagnosis

Explanation of other options:

CLL/SLL (Option A): Shows small mature lymphocytes and smudge cells; eosinophils and basophils are not seen

Burkitt lymphoma (Option B): Typically does not show peripheral blood involvement; known for "starry-sky" pattern on lymph node biopsy

Hairy cell leukaemia (Option D): Characterised by cells with cytoplasmic projections ("hairy cells"); usually presents with pancytopenia, not leukocytosis

Key Takeaways:

  • CML presents with basophilia, eosinophilia, and a full spectrum of granulocytic precursors
  • CLL → mature lymphocytes; CML → myeloid series
  • Peripheral smear is essential for differentiating chronic leukaemias

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with a 3-week history of abdominal discomfort. Physical examination demonstrates splenomegaly but no lymphadenopathy. A CBC shows pancytopenia. Examination of a peripheral blood smear reveals atypical lymphoid cells that exhibit tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase activity. Which of the following is the appropriate diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Hairy cell leukaemia is a clonal B-cell neoplasm of small to medium-sized lymphocytes with abundant pale cytoplasm and hair-like cytoplasmic projections
  • Commonly affects middle-aged to elderly men with a male-to-female ratio of 5:1
  • Presents with splenomegaly, abdominal discomfort, and pancytopenia
  • Peripheral smear reveals "hairy cells" that are tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase (TRAP) positive
  • Disease involves the bone marrow, spleen, and liver (monocyte/macrophage system)
  • Lymphadenopathy is typically absent

Explanation of other options:

Acute lymphocytic leukaemia (Option A): Typically affects children, not middle-aged adults. Presents with abrupt onset of symptoms (e.g., fever, fatigue, bleeding). Peripheral smear shows lymphoblasts, not mature lymphoid cells with projections. No association with TRAP positivity

Chronic lymphocytic leukaemia (Option B): Common in the elderly but presents with lymphocytosis, smudge cells, and generalised lymphadenopathy, TRAP-negative, and no hairy projections on smear

Chronic myelogenous leukaemia (Option C): Characterised by marked leukocytosis with basophilia and Philadelphia chromosome (t(9;22)), not associated with pancytopenia or TRAP activity

Key Takeaways:

  • Hairy cell leukaemia presents with TRAP-positive lymphoid cells and pancytopenia
  • Absence of lymphadenopathy helps distinguish it from CLL
  • Middle-aged men with splenomegaly and a "fried-egg" appearance on marrow aspirate are classic

questions.text: A 48-year-old alcoholic man presents with a 6-day history of productive cough and fever. The temperature is 38.7°C (103°F), respirations are 32 per minute, and blood pressure is 125/85 mm Hg. The patient's cough worsens, and he begins expectorating large amounts of foul-smelling sputum. A chest X-ray shows a right upper and middle lobe infiltrate. A CBC demonstrates leukocytosis (WBC = 38,000/mL), with 80% slightly immature neutrophils and toxic granulation. Laboratory studies reveal elevated leukocyte alkaline phosphatase. Which of the following best describes this patient's hematologic condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Leukemoid reaction is a benign, reactive neutrophilic leukocytosis seen in severe infections
  • The patient has foul-smelling sputum, high-grade fever, right-sided infiltrates, and a WBC count of 38,000/mL with toxic granulation
  • Peripheral smear shows slightly immature neutrophils, not blasts, which is consistent with a reactive myeloid response
  • Elevated leukocyte alkaline phosphatase (LAP) score distinguishes it from CML, where LAP is decreased

Explanation of other options:

Acute myelogenous leukaemia (Option A): Typically presents with anaemia, thrombocytopenia, and circulating blasts; LAP score is not elevated

Chronic lymphocytic leukaemia (Option B): Characterised by mature lymphocytosis and smudge cells, not neutrophilia

Chronic myelogenous leukaemia (Option C): May have a similar WBC count but shows a full spectrum of granulocytes, basophilia, and a low LAP score

Key Takeaways:

  • Leukemoid reaction mimics leukaemia but is reactive and benign
  • High LAP score and toxic granulation help distinguish from CML
  • Triggered by severe infections, especially in alcoholic, immunocompromised patients

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy presented with easy fatigability for 2 weeks. At present, he complains of a sudden onset of vertigo. He advised a peripheral smear examination to look for any blood-related cause. An image of the peripheral is shown below. Based on the above findings, what is your probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • ALL is the most common leukaemia in children and adolescents, typically presenting with fatigue, anaemia, and CNS symptoms like vertigo
  • Peripheral smear shows lymphoblasts: cells with scant basophilic cytoplasm, high N: C ratio, condensed chromatin, and inconspicuous nucleoli
  • The nuclear membrane may be convoluted, giving a hand mirror appearance
  • Compared to myeloblasts, lymphoblasts have denser chromatin, less cytoplasm, and lack granules

Explanation of other options:

Chronic lymphocytic leukaemia (Option B): Occurs in the elderly with mature lymphocytosis; smudge cells are typical; not seen in children

Chronic myelogenous leukaemia (Option C): Features a full myeloid spectrum with eosinophils/basophils; rare in children

Acute myelogenous leukaemia (Option D): Myeloblasts have more prominent nucleoli, Auer rods, and less condensed chromatin

Key Takeaways:

  • ALL is the most common leukaemia in children
  • Lymphoblasts = condensed chromatin, inconspicuous nucleoli, scant cytoplasm
  • Peripheral smear morphology is key to distinguishing AML

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient presented for routine examination. His CBC shows 90% lymphocytes, and a peripheral smear examination was done to confirm the diagnosis, the image of which is shown below. Identify the possible cause.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Chronic Lymphocytic Leukaemia (CLL) is the most common leukaemia in older adults, often detected incidentally during routine tests
  • CBC with 90% lymphocytes in a 65-year-old is highly suggestive of CLL
  • Peripheral smear shows numerous small, mature lymphocytes with scant cytoplasm and characteristic smudge cells due to cell fragility during smear preparation
  • CLL and Small Lymphocytic Lymphoma (SLL) are morphologically and immunophenotypically identical, differing only by the degree of peripheral blood involvement

Explanation of other options:

CML (Option B): Features myeloid hyperplasia with granulocytic precursors and basophilia, not isolated lymphocytosis

AML (Option C): Presents with myeloblasts with Auer rods and pancytopenia, not mature lymphocytosis

PV (Option D): Characterised by erythrocytosis, not lymphocytosis or smudge cells

Key Takeaways:

  • CLL/SLL shows mature lymphocytosis and smudge cells on peripheral smear
  • Common in older adults, often asymptomatic at diagnosis
  • Involves the bone marrow, spleen, and liver

questions.text: A 27-year-old man presents with an 8-week history of fevers, chills, pruritus, and night sweats. Two months ago, he experienced a flu-like illness. A nagging cough with occasional hemoptysis persisted for several weeks following the resolution of his other symptoms. Physical examination reveals moderately enlarged, firm, nontender lymph nodes located in the right supraclavicular region. A lymph node biopsy is shown in the image. What is the appropriate diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • A young adult with B symptoms (fever, chills, night sweats) and firm, nontender supraclavicular lymphadenopathy is classic for Hodgkin lymphoma
  • Nodular sclerosis subtype is the most common form of classical HL, especially in young adults
  • Histology shows bands of collagenous fibrosis surrounding nodules of inflammatory cells
  • The diagnostic hallmark is the presence of the lacunar variant of Reed-Sternberg cells within fibrous nodules

Explanation of other options:

Mixed cellularity, Hodgkin's lymphoma (Option B): More common in older individuals; lacks nodular sclerosis or lacunar RS cells

DLBCL (Option C): A type of non-Hodgkin lymphoma; presents with a rapidly enlarging mass and lacks Reed-Sternberg cells

Mycosis fungoides (Option D): A cutaneous T-cell lymphoma; primarily affects skin with patches, plaques, or tumours, not cervical lymph nodes

Key Takeaways:

  • Nodular sclerosis HL = most common classical subtype, age 20-30
  • Lacunar RS cells + fibrous bands are diagnostic
  • Presents with B symptoms and mediastinal or supraclavicular nodes

questions.text: A 20-year-old carpenter with a wound infection on his left thumb presents with an enlarged and tender lymph node in the axilla. A lymph node biopsy shows follicular enlargement and hyperemia. The sinuses are filled with neutrophils. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • A young adult with a local wound infection and a tender, enlarged axillary node indicates draining lymphadenitis
  • Histology shows follicular hyperplasia, hyperemia, and sinus infiltration by neutrophils, all hallmark features of acute suppurative lymphadenitis
  • Pain and rapid enlargement occur due to capsular distention from oedema and inflammation

Explanation of other options:

Castleman disease (Option A): Non-neoplastic lymphoproliferative disorder; lacks neutrophilic infiltration and suppuration

Histiocytosis X (Option B): Involves Langerhans cells, eosinophils; affects bones and skin rather than lymph nodes

Interfollicular hyperplasia (Option C): Common in viral infections; shows paracortical expansion without neutrophil-dominated sinuses

Key Takeaways:

  • Suppurative lymphadenitis involves neutrophil-rich sinus infiltration
  • Typically follows an acute bacterial infection in the draining area
  • Distinguished histologically by prominent neutrophils and follicular hyperplasia

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient presented to the casualty, complaining of easy tiredness and weakness for 1 year. CBC performed shows high TLC, and automated differential counts suggested monocytosis. Peripheral smear examination was done and is shown below. Based on characteristic features, what is your probable diagnosis
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Acute Promyelocytic Leukaemia (AML M3) presents with abnormal promyelocytes that have dense azurophilic granules
  • Nuclei are often bilobed or kidney-shaped, with cytoplasm obscured by prominent granules
  • Faggot cells: promyelocytes containing bundled Auer rods are pathognomonic
  • Clinical signs may include cytopenias, coagulopathy, and monocytosis on automated counts due to cytomorphologic overlap

Explanation of other options:

ALL (Option A): Lymphoblasts show scant basophilic cytoplasm, condensed chromatin, and lack granules or Auer rods

AML, M2 (Option B): Shows myeloblasts with Auer rods, but without prominent granularity or faggot cells

AML, M5 (Option D): Monocytic predominance; cells lack Auer rod bundles and display folded or lobulated nuclei

Key Takeaways:

  • AML M3 is characterised by faggot cells and bilobed nuclei with heavy granulation
  • Diagnosis for acute promyelocytic leukaemia, associated with t(15;17)
  • Requires prompt treatment with ATRA due to DIC risk

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with several enlarged lymph nodes in his left supraclavicular region. Physical examination reveals painless lymphadenopathy in this region. No other abnormalities are found. A biopsy from one of these enlarged lymph nodes, which is shown in the associated picture, reveals effacement of the normal lymph-node architecture by numerous nodules of uniform size that are found crowded within the cortex and medulla of the lymph node. Tingible body macrophages are not seen in these nodules. Which one of the listed chromosomal translocations is most closely associated with this type of lymphoma?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient has painless supraclavicular lymphadenopathy, typical of non-Hodgkin lymphoma
  • Histology reveals nodular architecture, monotonous B cells, and absence of tingible body macrophages, consistent with follicular lymphoma
  • Follicular lymphoma is a nodular B-cell neoplasm derived from germinal centre B cells, often involving both cortex and medulla
  • The hallmark genetic abnormality is t(14;18) translocation → leads to overexpression of BCL2, an anti-apoptotic protein
  • BCL2 overexpression prevents apoptosis of germinal centre B cells, contributing to lymphoma pathogenesis

Explanation of other options:

t(2;8) (Option A): Associated with Burkitt lymphoma, not follicular lymphoma

t(8;22) (Option B): Also, a translocation seen in Burkitt lymphoma

t(9;14) (Option C): Seen in lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma, not follicular subtype

Key Takeaways:

  • Follicular lymphoma = nodular, B-cell, painless lymphadenopathy
  • t(14;18) → BCL2 overexpression → inhibits apoptosis
  • Histology lacks tingible body macrophages and shows uniform nodules

questions.text: A 55-year-old man complains of pain in his back, fatigue, and occasional confusion. He admits to polyuria and polydipsia. An X-ray examination reveals numerous lytic lesions in the lumbar vertebral bodies. Laboratory studies disclose hypoalbuminemia, mild anaemia, and thrombocytopenia. A monoclonal Igk peak is demonstrated by serum electrophoresis. Urinalysis shows 4+ proteinuria. A bone marrow biopsy discloses foci of plasma cells, which account for 18% of all hematopoietic cells. What is the appropriate diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient presents with bone pain, fatigue, polyuria/polydipsia, and confusion, suggestive of hypercalcemia
  • X-ray shows lytic bone lesions, a hallmark of multiple myeloma
  • Lab findings: monoclonal Igκ spike, proteinuria (Bence-Jones protein), anaemia, thrombocytopenia, and hypoalbuminemia
  • Bone marrow with ≥10% plasma cells confirms the diagnosis
  • Multiple myeloma is characterised by malignant plasma cell infiltration producing monoclonal immunoglobulin and associated end-organ damage (CRAB: Calcium elevation, Renal failure, Anaemia, Bone lesions)

Explanation of other options:

Acute lymphoblastic lymphoma (Option A): Occurs primarily in children; not associated with plasma cells or M-protein

Chronic lymphocytic leukaemia (Option B): Involves small mature lymphocytes and smudge cells; no lytic lesions or monoclonal spike

Extramedullary plasmacytoma (Option C): Localised plasma cell tumour without systemic involvement or bone marrow plasmacytosis

Key Takeaways:

  • Multiple myeloma = monoclonal protein, lytic bone lesions, ≥10% plasma cells
  • Presents with CRAB symptoms and M-spike on electrophoresis
  • Bence-Jones proteinuria is a classic finding

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common immunologic type of multiple myeloma?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • IgG is the most common M protein produced in multiple myeloma, accounting for ~60% of cases
  • Followed by IgA (~20-25%), IgD, IgE, and IgM are rare
  • Myeloma cells produce either kappa (κ) or lambda (λ) light chains, but not both
  • Free light chains are filtered by the kidneys and appear in urine as Bence Jones proteins
  • IgG with κ light chain combination is the most frequent immunoglobulin pattern seen in patients

Explanation of other options:

IgA, kappa light chain (Option B): Less common than IgG; seen in ~20-25% of cases

IgD, lambda light chain (Option C): Very rare subtype; associated with aggressive disease

IgM (Option D): Not typical of myeloma; more commonly seen in Waldenström's macroglobulinemia

Key Takeaways:

  • IgG κ is the most common immunologic type in multiple myeloma
  • Bence Jones proteins are free light chains excreted in urine
  • Detection of the M protein helps in diagnosis and monitoring

questions.text: Flame cells are diagnostic of?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Flame cells are atypical plasma cells with bright red-purple cytoplasm on Wright-Giemsa stain
  • Seen most commonly in IgA myeloma, but can also occur in non-IgA myelomas, MGUS, and reactive plasmacytosis
  • The flame-like appearance is due to the high carbohydrate content in the cytoplasm, especially from IgA molecules
  • The presence of flame cells in bone marrow smears supports the diagnosis of plasma cell dyscrasias, particularly multiple myeloma

Explanation of other options:

Leukaemia (Option B): Involves blasts or mature white cells; does not show flame cells

Ewing's sarcoma (Option C): Small round blue cell tumour of bone; unrelated to plasma cells

Osteosarcoma (Option D): Malignant bone tumour with osteoid formation; not associated with flame cells

Key Takeaways:

  • Flame cells = red-purple cytoplasm in IgA myeloma
  • Reflect the plasma cell origin with high carbohydrate content
  • Diagnostic clue in multiple myeloma evaluation

questions.text: Bence Jones proteins, commonly identified in the urine of patients with plasma cell disorders such as multiple myeloma, are composed of which of the following immunoglobulin components?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Bence Jones proteins are free immunoglobulin light chains (κ or λ)
  • These are produced by malignant plasma cells, commonly in multiple myeloma
  • Due to their small molecular size, they are filtered through the kidneys and excreted in the urine
  • Bence Jones proteins may be produced alone or along with complete immunoglobulins
  • Their detection is used to support the diagnosis and monitoring of plasma cell disorders

Explanation of other options:

Heavy chains (Option A): Not excreted in urine due to larger size; not referred to as Bence Jones proteins

Heavy and light chains (Option C): Refers to complete immunoglobulins, not Bence Jones proteins

Immunoglobulin (Option D): Bence Jones proteins are components (light chains), not whole immunoglobulins

Key Takeaways:

  • Bence Jones proteins = free light chains (κ or λ)
  • Found in the urine of patients with multiple myeloma
  • Diagnostic for plasma cell dyscrasias

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents with progressive fatigue and generalised lymphadenopathy. Routine blood work reveals marked lymphocytosis. A peripheral smear shows numerous small, mature-looking lymphocytes with scattered smudge cells. Which of the following investigations would provide the most definitive confirmation of the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Chronic Lymphocytic Leukaemia (CLL) is a mature B-cell neoplasm characterised by the accumulation of monoclonal B lymphocytes
  • Flow cytometry is the definitive diagnostic tool as it detects the characteristic immunophenotype: CD19+, CD20+ (dim), CD5+, and CD23+
  • It distinguishes CLL from other lymphoproliferative disorders, such as mantle cell lymphoma
  • It also quantifies the monoclonal B-cell population and helps confirm diagnosis in early or atypical cases

Flow Cytometry:

Explanation of other options:

FISH (Option A): Useful for detecting prognostic cytogenetic abnormalities (e.g., del(13q), del(11q), del(17p)), but not diagnostic

BMBX (Option C): Bone marrow biopsy is not required for diagnosis, but may be done for staging or in ambiguous cases

Cytogenetics: 13q del (Option D): Common prognostic marker in CLL, but not used for primary diagnosis

Key Takeaways:

  • Flow cytometry is the gold standard for diagnosing CLL
  • CLL shows co-expression of CD5 and CD23 on B cells
  • Cytogenetic studies guide prognosis, not diagnosis

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presented with low back pain. Investigations revealed Hb 13 g%, Calcium 13 mg/dL, and urine protein 3+. What is the underlying diagnosis responsible for renal failure?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Flow cytometry is the definitive diagnostic test for CLL
  • Detects a clonal population of B lymphocytes with a characteristic immunophenotype: CD19+, CD20 (dim), CD5+, CD23+
  • It differentiates CLL from other B-cell neoplasms like mantle cell lymphoma
  • Peripheral smear and lymphocytosis raise suspicion, but flow cytometry confirms the diagnosis

Explanation of other options:

FISH (Option A): Detects cytogenetic abnormalities (e.g., del(13q), del(17p)) but is used for prognosis, not confirmation

Bone marrow biopsy (Option C): Helpful for staging and evaluation of marrow involvement, not required for diagnosis

Cytogenetic analysis for 13q deletion (Option D): Common prognostic marker; not diagnostic or confirmatory

Key Takeaways:

  • Flow cytometry is the most accurate and confirmatory test for CLL
  • CD5+/CD23+ B-cell phenotype is a diagnostic hallmark
  • Cytogenetics = prognostic, not diagnostic

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the diagnostic criteria of multiple myeloma?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Multiple myeloma diagnostic criteria (CRAB criteria + clonal evidence) includes:
    • C: Calcium elevation (serum calcium >10.5 mg/dL)
    • R: Renal insufficiency (creatinine >2 mg/dL) (Option B)
    • A: Anaemia (Hb <10 g/dL or 2 g below normal)
    • B: Lytic bone lesions or osteoporosis (Option A)
  • Plasmacytoma on biopsy and monoclonal protein in serum/urine are also part of the diagnosis (Option D)
  • Hypocalcemia is not part of the diagnostic criteria and is not associated with multiple myeloma

Key Takeaways:

  • Diagnostic criteria for MM: Clonal plasma cells + CRAB features
  • Hypercalcemia, not hypocalcemia, is characteristic
  • A biopsy-proven plasmacytoma confirms a plasma cell neoplasm

questions.text: Which of the following is the best prognostic indicator of multiple myeloma at the time of diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Beta-2 microglobulin is the most reliable prognostic indicator in multiple myeloma
  • High levels correlate with increased tumour burden and poorer survival
  • Median survival:
    • < 0.004 g/L → ~43 months
    • > 0.004 g/L → ~12 months
  • Myeloma cells in marrow confirm diagnosis, but don't predict prognosis (Option A ruled out)
  • Alkaline phosphatase is elevated in bone turnover but not prognostic for MM (Option C ruled out)
  • Hypercalcemia is a feature of MM but not a predictor of outcome (Option D ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • Beta-2 microglobulin is the single best prognostic marker in multiple myeloma
  • Prognostic value relates to tumour load and renal function
  • Diagnostic and prognostic markers are distinct in MM

questions.text: A 50-year-old male complained of fatigability that persisted for one year. Mild anaemia, massive splenomegaly. Hb 10 gm%, TLC of 1.2 lakhs, platelets 5 lakhs/ul, Neutrophils 60, Basophil 4, Eosinophil 6, Lymph 15, Myeloblast 3. The rest were myelocytes and bands. M:E ratio of 18:1, Most specific further investigation:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Chronic Myeloid Leukaemia (CML) is strongly suspected based on:
    • Marked leukocytosis with left shift (↑myelocytes, bands, few blasts)
    • Basophilia + eosinophilia
    • Massive splenomegaly
    • High M: E ratio (18:1)
  • FISH or PCR for the BCR-ABL fusion gene is the most specific and confirmatory test
  • Immunophenotyping is used in lymphoid malignancies (Option B ruled out)
  • PET-CT is for lymphoma staging, not CML diagnosis (Option C ruled out)
  • Leucocyte Alkaline Phosphatase (LAP) helps differentiate CML from leukemoid reaction, but is not confirmatory (Option D ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • The BCR-ABL fusion gene (Philadelphia chromosome) confirms CML
  • FISH/PCR is the definitive test for diagnosis
  • Hematologic findings + splenomegaly should prompt molecular testing

questions.text: Which of the following genetic abnormalities is not included in the pathogenesis of myelodysplastic syndrome?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Common cytogenetic abnormalities in Myelodysplastic Syndrome (MDS) include:
    • Monosomy 5 → frequently seen
    • Trisomy 8 → one of the most common gains in MDS (Option C is correct; not ruled out)
    • Deletion of 20q → another recurrent finding in MDS (Option D is correct; not ruled out)
    • Monosomy 6 is not associated with MDS (Option B ruled in as the correct answer)
  • These chromosomal abnormalities often reflect loss of tumour suppressor genes or dysregulation of epigenetic mechanisms

Key Takeaways:

  • MDS is associated with monosomy 5, monosomy 7, del(5q), del(7q), del(20q), trisomy 8
  • Monosomy 6 is not part of MDS pathogenesis
  • Cytogenetic analysis plays a key role in prognosis and classification

questions.text: Which is the commonest site for the lytic lesion to occur in a case of multiple myeloma?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Lytic bone lesions in multiple myeloma are due to osteoclast activation mediated by cytokines like IL-6 and RANKL
  • These lesions are most frequently seen in the axial skeleton, especially the vertebral column
  • Order of frequency:
    • Vertebral column > Ribs > Pelvis > Femur > Clavicle > Skull (Options B, C and D ruled out)
  • Vertebrae are highly vascular and rich in hematopoietic marrow, explaining their predisposition

Key Takeaways:

  • The vertebral column is the most common site for lytic lesions in multiple myeloma
  • Lytic lesions are due to osteolysis without reactive bone formation
  • Lesions appear as punched-out defects on radiographs

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in both myeloproliferation and myelodysplasia?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • JMML is classified under myeloproliferative neoplasms in the 2022 WHO classification
  • It is not part of the overlap category that includes both myeloproliferation and myelodysplasia
  • Chronic myelomonocytic leukaemia (CMML) is the classic example that fits both myeloproliferative and myelodysplastic features
  • Hence, JMML is excluded from the overlap group

Explanation of other options:

Chronic myelomonocytic leukaemia (Option A): Falls under myelodysplastic/myeloproliferative overlap syndromes per WHO

Key Takeaways:

  • JMML is a myeloproliferative disorder per WHO 2022
  • CMML belongs to the overlap syndrome category
  • Classification matters for prognosis and therapy decisions

questions.text: The most malignant form of NHL
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL) is the most common and the most malignant form of NHL in adults, accounting for about 35% of adult NHLs.
  • Around one-third of DLBCL cases show BCL6 gene rearrangements on chromosome 3q27.
  • Many also harbour activating point mutations in the BCL6 promoter, leading to overexpression of BCL6 protein, a key transcriptional regulator in germinal centre B cells.
  • About 30% of tumours exhibit t(14;18) translocation involving the BCL2 gene, resulting in overexpression of the BCL2 protein.
  • Some DLBCL cases represent "transformed" follicular lymphomas, while others carry distinct driver mutations such as MYC gene translocations.
  • Clinically, DLBCL presents as a rapidly enlarging lymph node mass in nodal or extranodal sites. Despite its aggressive nature, it is highly responsive to chemotherapy.

Explanation of other options:

Small cell lymphocytic lymphoma (Option B): A low-grade, indolent lymphoma that progresses slowly and is not considered the most malignant form of NHL.

Follicular cleavage (Option C): Refers to a histological feature of follicular lymphoma. Follicular lymphoma is generally indolent, not highly malignant.

Large cell follicular (Option D): Refers to follicular lymphoma grade 3 with larger cells but still less aggressive compared to DLBCL.

questions.text: Lacunar cells are seen in-
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Lacunar cells are a variant of Reed-Sternberg cells
  • Characterised by a multilobate nucleus, small nucleoli, and abundant pale cytoplasm
  • On fixation, cytoplasmic retraction creates a clear space ("lacune")
  • Found in the Nodular sclerosis subtype of classical Hodgkin lymphoma

Explanation of other options:

Mixed cellularity (Option A): Contains classic RS cells but lacks lacunar variants

Lymphocyte predominance (Option B): Shows L&H ("popcorn") cells, not lacunar cells

Lymphocyte depletion (Option C): Exhibits pleomorphic RS cells, not lacunar forms

Key Takeaways:

  • Lacunar cells are specific to Nodular sclerosis Hodgkin lymphoma
  • Formed due to cytoplasmic retraction during fixation
  • Absent in other classical and non-classical subtypes

choices.text: Most cases in HIV-positive patients are associated with Epstein-Barr virus infection.
This disease is caused by upregulation of the c-myc oncogene
Tumour lysis syndrome is uncommon in this disease
The disease is usually unresponsive to chemotherapy

questions.text: A 7-year-old Nigerian child is treated at a regional medical center for a facial tumor. The mass is located within the mandible itself. Biopsy reveals sheets of medium-sized neoplastic cells that stain deep blue on Giemsa stain with numerous vacuoles in the cytoplasm, interspersed with macrophages. Which of the following is true regarding this patient's disease?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Burkitt lymphoma is a high-grade B-cell lymphoma
  • Defined by translocation involving the c-myc oncogene, commonly t(8;14)
  • The translocation leads to upregulation of c-myc, driving uncontrolled cell proliferation
  • Deep blue cytoplasm with vacuoles and "starry-sky" appearance support the diagnosis
  • This tumour shows rapid growth but is also highly sensitive to chemotherapy

Explanation of other options:

Most of the cases in HIV-positive patients are associated with Epstein-Barr virus infection (Option A): Only ~30% of immunodeficiency-associated cases are EBV-positive, unlike >95% in endemic type

Tumour lysis syndrome is uncommon in this disease (Option C): It is actually very common due to the high proliferation rate

The disease is usually unresponsive to chemotherapy (Option D): Burkitt lymphoma is very responsive to chemotherapy

Key Takeaways:

  • c-myc translocation is the hallmark of Burkitt lymphoma
  • The endemic variant commonly affects the jaw/mandible in African children
  • High risk of tumour lysis due to extremely fast growth, yet chemo-sensitive

choices.text: Only i, ii, and iii are correct
Only i and iii are correct
Only ii and iv are correct

questions.text:
EBV positivity is found in which of the following types of Hodgkin's disease?
i) Lymphocyte-depleted
ii) Mixed Cellularity
iii) Lymphocyte Rich
iv) Nodular Sclerosis
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • EBV positivity is found in ~100% of lymphocyte-depleted HL cases
  • Mixed cellularity HL is strongly associated with EBV (~75% of cases)
  • Lymphocyte-rich HL shows EBV positivity in a subset, though less than LD and MC
  • Nodular sclerosis HL is the least associated with EBV (only ~10-25% of cases)

Key Takeaways:

  • EBV positivity is highest in LDHL and MCHL
  • Nodular sclerosis HL has the weakest association with EBV
  • NLPHL is EBV-negative by definition

questions.text: Mantle cell lymphoma is positive for all except?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Mantle cell lymphoma arises from naïve B cells in the mantle zone
  • It is associated with t(11;14) translocation, causing cyclin D1 overexpression
  • Tumour cells are CD20+, CD5+, CD43+ (Options B, C and D)
  • CD23 is typically negative, which helps differentiate it from CLL/SLL (which is CD23 positive)

Key Takeaways:

  • CD23 negativity is characteristic of Mantle cell lymphoma
  • Positive for CD20, CD5, CD43, and cyclin D1
  • Associated with t(11;14) → cyclin D1 overexpression

questions.text: Which of the following lymphomas is triggered by autoimmune disorders?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Extranodal marginal zone lymphoma (MALT lymphoma) develops in chronic inflammatory settings.
  • It is often triggered by autoimmune disorders such as:
    • Sjögren syndrome → salivary gland involvement
    • Hashimoto thyroiditis → thyroid involvement
  • Also associated with chronic infections, most notably Helicobacter pylori infection in the gastric mucosa.
  • Tumour growth is maintained by inflammatory cytokines from antigen-specific T cells.
  • These lymphomas can regress if the underlying cause (e.g., H. pylori infection) is treated or eradicated.

Explanation of other options:

Follicular lymphoma (Option A): Typically linked to t(14;18) translocation and BCL2 overexpression. It is not autoimmune-triggered.

Hodgkin's lymphoma (Option B): Characterised by Reed-Sternberg cells, often associated with EBV infection, not autoimmunity.

Mantle cell lymphoma (Option C): Associated with t(11;14) translocation leading to cyclin D1 overexpression; not related to autoimmune disorders.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common extranodal site for non-Hodgkin's lymphoma?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL) often presents at extranodal sites
  • The most common extranodal site is the gastrointestinal tract
  • Within the GI tract, the stomach is the most frequently involved organ
  • Common in MALT lymphoma, often linked to H.pylori infection

Explanation of other options:

Intestines (Option B): Can be involved in NHL (e.g., ileocecal region), but stomach remains more common.

Thyroid (Option C): Lymphoma of the thyroid is rare, usually linked to Hashimoto thyroiditis, not the most common site overall.

Brain (Option D): Primary CNS lymphoma occurs mainly in immunocompromised patients (e.g., HIV), but it is much less common than gastric involvement.

Key Takeaways:

  • The stomach is the most common extranodal site for NHL
  • Extranodal involvement occurs in ~2/3 of NHL cases
  • Strong association with chronic inflammation/infection (e.g., H. pylori)

questions.text: Which of the following is not a B-cell lymphoma?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Mycosis fungoides is a cutaneous T-cell lymphoma
  • Arises from mature CD4+ T-cells
  • Typically presents with skin involvement (patches, plaques, tumours)
  • It is not of B-cell lineage, unlike the others

Precursor B Cell Neoplasms

  • Precursor B cell leukemia/lymphoma (B-ALL)

Peripheral B Cell Neoplasms

  • B cell chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) / small lymphocytic lymphoma (SLL)
  • B cell prolymphocytic leukemia
  • Lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma
  • Mantle cell lymphoma
  • Follicular lymphoma
  • Extranodal marginal zone lymphoma
  • Splenic and nodal marginal zone lymphoma
  • Hairy cell leukemia
  • Plasmacytoma / plasma cell myeloma
  • Diffuse large B cell lymphoma (multiple subtypes)
  • Burkitt lymphoma

Precursor T Cell Neoplasms

  • Precursor T cell leukemia/lymphoma (T-ALL)

Peripheral T/NK Cell Neoplasms

  • T cell prolymphocytic leukemia
  • T cell granular lymphocytic leukemia
  • Mycosis fungoides / Sézary syndrome
  • Peripheral T cell lymphoma, unspecified
  • Angioimmunoblastic T cell lymphoma
  • Anaplastic large cell lymphoma
  • Enteropathy-type T cell lymphoma
  • Panniculitis-like T cell lymphoma
  • Hepatosplenic γδ T cell lymphoma
  • Adult T cell lymphoma/leukemia
  • Extranodal NK/T cell lymphoma
  • Aggressive NK cell leukemia

Hodgkin Lymphoma

  • Nodular sclerosis
  • Mixed cellularity
  • Lymphocyte-rich
  • Lymphocyte-depleted
  • Lymphocyte predominant

Explanation of other options:

Follicular lymphoma (Option A): A B-cell lymphoma derived from germinal centre B cells

Burkitt lymphoma (Option C): A high-grade B-cell lymphoma associated with c-myc translocation

Mantle cell lymphoma (Option D): A B-cell lymphoma with t(11;14) translocation and cyclin D1 overexpression

Key Takeaways:

  • Mycosis fungoides is the only T-cell lymphoma among the options
  • The other three are B-cell lineage
  • WHO classification divides lymphomas by B- or T-cell origin

choices.text: A-1, B-2, C-3, D-4, E-5, F-6
A-2, B-1, C-4, D-5, E-6, F-3
A-3, B-4, C-1, D-2, E-5, F-6
A-6, B-2, C-5, D-1, E-3, F-4

questions.text: Match the following lymphomas/neoplasms with their associated marker or genetic feature:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Follicular lymphoma → BCL2 positivity from t(14;18) (A-1)
  • Mycosis fungoides → CD4+ T-cell lymphoma with skin involvement (B-2)
  • Mantle cell lymphoma → Cyclin D1 overexpression from t(11;14) (C-3)
  • Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma → Aggressive, CD20+ B-cell neoplasm (D-4)
  • Burkitt lymphoma → c-myc translocation t(8;14) (E-5)
  • Extranodal marginal zone lymphoma → Arises in autoimmune/inflammatory settings (F-6)

Key Takeaways:

  • Each lymphoma has a distinctive immunophenotype or genetic hallmark
  • B-cell neoplasms often involve translocations and overexpression of oncogenes like BCL-2, Cyclin D1, c-myc
  • T-cell lymphoma (e.g., Mycosis fungoides) presents differently with cutaneous involvement
  • Marginal zone lymphoma is linked to chronic inflammation or infection

questions.text: Identify the cells marked:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Eosinophils have bilobed nuclei and large eosinophilic (pink/red-orange) granules
  • The cell marked in the image shows a bilobed nucleus with distinct red cytoplasmic granules
  • Neutrophils have multilobed nuclei and finer, less eosinophilic granules (Option A ruled out)
  • Monocytes are larger cells with kidney-shaped nuclei and abundant blue-grey cytoplasm, lacking granules (Option B ruled out)
  • Lymphocytes have a large, round nucleus with scant cytoplasm and no granules (Option D ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • Eosinophils have bilobed nuclei and coarse eosinophilic granules
  • Their granules contain major basic protein and are involved in parasitic defence
  • Easily distinguished on peripheral smear by pink-orange granulation

questions.text: Blood examination shows pancytopenia with hypocellular bone marrow, which can be correct?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Fanconi anaemia is an inherited bone marrow failure syndrome
  • Characterised by pancytopenia with hypocellular marrow
  • It leads to aplastic anaemia due to genetic defects in DNA repair
  • Megaloblastic anaemia shows hypercellular marrow with megaloblasts (Option A ruled out)
  • Hairy cell leukaemia presents with pancytopenia and splenomegaly, but the marrow is typically fibrotic, not hypocellular (Option B ruled out)
  • APML (Acute Promyelocytic Leukaemia) shows hypercellular marrow filled with abnormal promyelocytes (Option D ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • Fanconi anaemia → hypocellular marrow + pancytopenia
  • Distinguish from other causes of pancytopenia by marrow cellularity
  • Caused by DNA repair defects, often with congenital anomalies
